citations.narrative:
As reported by a facility representative, on July 22, 2025 one of the exhibits in the Tropical Bird House (TBH) was
discovered to be empty that normally housed two Blue dacnis, two Red-cheeked cordon bleu, one Violaceous euphonia,
and one Purple honeycreeper. The closing keeper confirmed seeing five of the six birds (all but the Violaceous euphonia)
the night before at closing and the line keeper confirmed seeing all six birds several times while working in/around the
exhibit in days before. The staff made corrective actions by breaking down the exhibit, but no evidence of bird or pest
activity was found. As documented on the letter to the AZA Accreditation Committee, on August 6, 2025, a Turquoise
tanager was found dead in the neighboring exhibit while another was missing. The facility immediately pulled all birds in
the south building and broke down the exhibit where they located a black rat snake. Radiographs of the snake confirmed
a collection bird that had been eaten (presence of band on the leg) and another band seen further down in the snake’s
digestive track. A sizable shed was discovered near the snake’s hiding place as well as several fecal that contained
feathers and bands from the first exhibit’s residence. Since removing the snake, the south tunnel of the bird house has
been left vacant, and staff are systematically stripping and reframing the top of each exhibit in order to replace lumber and
mesh and minimize any gapping that could allow future pests to gain egress. Birds that disappear from their primary
enclosure or that are not protected from predation may suffer from stress, injury, or death. Correct by ensuring that bird
enclosures are maintained in good repair, protect the birds from injury, contain the birds, and restrict other animals from
entering who may negatively affect the welfare of the birds within. Corrected prior to time of inspection on 9/3/2025.
This inspection and exit interview were conducted with a facility representative.
Additional Inspectors:
TANESHA WILKINS, SACS n

narrative:
3.150(a)  Critical Repeat
   
Facilities, general. 
As reported by a facility representative, on July 22, 2025 one of the exhibits in the Tropical Bird House (TBH) was 
discovered to be empty that normally housed two Blue dacnis, two Red-cheeked cordon bleu, one Violaceous euphonia, 
and one Purple honeycreeper. The closing keeper confirmed seeing five of the six birds (all but the Violaceous euphonia) 
the night before at closing and the line keeper confirmed seeing all six birds several times while working in/around the 
exhibit in days before. The staff made corrective actions by breaking down the exhibit, but no evidence of bird or pest 
activity was found. As documented on the letter to the AZA Accreditation Committee, on August 6, 2025, a Turquoise 
tanager was found dead in the neighboring exhibit while another was missing. The facility immediately pulled all birds in 
the south building and broke down the exhibit where they located a black rat snake. Radiographs of the snake confirmed 
a collection bird that had been eaten (presence of band on the leg) and another band seen further down in the snake’s 
digestive track. A sizable shed was discovered near the snake’s hiding place as well as several fecal that contained 
feathers and bands from the first exhibit’s residence. Since removing the snake, the south tunnel of the bird house has 
been left vacant, and staff are systematically stripping and reframing the top of each exhibit in order to replace lumber and 
mesh and minimize any gapping that could allow future pests to gain egress. Birds that disappear from their primary 
enclosure or that are not protected from predation may suffer from stress, injury, or death. Correct by ensuring that bird 
enclosures are maintained in good repair, protect the birds from injury, contain the birds, and restrict other animals from 
entering who may negatively affect the welfare of the birds within. Corrected prior to time of inspection on 9/3/2025. 
 
This inspection and exit interview were conducted with a facility representative. 
 
Additional Inspectors: 
TANESHA WILKINS, SACS n

species.common: SOUTHERN GIANT POUCHED RAT / EAST AFRICAN
